channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: The Rise of a New Centrism
item.description: In Washington, despite polarization, bipartisanship has somehow become normal.

item.title: Iranian President Helicopter Crash: Raisi Dies in Crash, Iranian State Media Report
item.description: President Ebrahim Raisi and Iran’s foreign minister were killed in a helicopter crash, leaving the country without two of its most influential figures.

item.title: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy: An ‘embarrassing’ amount of your success in your 20s depends on your attitude
item.description: But aspirational workers need to follow through on a can do attitude with action, Jessy added.

item.title: Iran’s President Dies in Crash, and Trump Trial Enters Final Days
item.description: Plus, Baltimore bridge ship to be moved.

item.title: Who Was Iran’s Foreign Minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian?
item.description: A hard-liner and career diplomat long focused on Iran’s relationships in the Middle East, he died in a helicopter crash that also killed Iran’s president.

item.title: Chinese state media hints that Beijing might ‘hit back’ against European probes by targeting wine, dairy and aircraft
item.description: The EU is investigating Chinese subsidies across a range of industries, threatening tariffs for electric carmakers and keeping firms out of rail and energy tenders.

item.title: Senate Inquiry Finds BMW Imported Cars Tied to Forced Labor in China
item.description: The report also found that Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen bought parts from a supplier the U.S. government had singled out for its practices in Xinjiang.

item.title: What to Know About Mohammad Mokhber, Iran’s Acting President
item.description: Mr. Mokhber has long been involved in business conglomerates tied to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He must hold elections for a new president within 50 days.

item.title: Gen Z fueling limited-time flavors like Sour Patch Kids Oreos and pink lemonade-flavored Kit Kats
item.description: Food companies are responding to the changing and expanding tastes of consumers while also trying to keep brands relevant and distinct to win space on crowded store shelves.

item.title: Was the 401(k) a Mistake?
item.description: Much of why Americans are retiring with so little money can be traced to the reliance on the retirement account.

item.title: Taiwan’s President Vows to Keep Island Safe Amid Chinese Pressure
item.description: President Lai Ching-te has pledged to stay on his predecessor’s narrow path of resisting Beijing without provoking it. It won’t be easy.

item.title: Utilities are doubling their 5-year electricity demand projections—but high interest rates and California's NEM 3.0 have U.S. solar in a holding pattern
item.description: Multiple macroeconomic and legislative challenges are slowing the growth of residential solar.

item.title: What to Know About Mohammad Mokhber, Iran’s Acting President
item.description: Mr. Mokhber has long been involved in business conglomerates tied to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He must hold elections for a new president within 50 days.

item.title: Back From War, These I.D.F. Soldiers Demand New Leadership
item.description: Some reservists in the Israel Defense Forces who have returned home from war are joining the growing calls within Israel for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition to step aside.

item.title: Beijing is spending $42 billion to save its slumping real estate sector. Analysts say it’s nowhere near enough
item.description: The decline in China’s sales of new homes accelerated in recent months, with households increasingly preferring to buy in the secondary market.
